title: New Caledonia: Six questions to understand the current crisis
summary: Tensions in the French overseas territory exploded on May 13, leaving 5 people dead and dozens injured four days later. The government declared a state of emergency on May 15.

title: Israel's army and Netanyahu are at odds over war in Gaza
summary: Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant has openly criticized the prime minister's refusal to establish a Palestinian political authority in Gaza, thus paving the way for the establishment of Israeli military rule.

title: Lyon win French title ahead of Women's Champions League final
summary: The 2-1 win over Paris Saint-Germain is good news for the team, who will be challenging Barcelona in the Champions League final on May 25.

title: Arab countries call for deployment of UN-mandated peacekeeping forces in occupied Palestinian territories
summary: Meeting in Bahrain, the 22 countries of the Arab League called for recognition of the Palestinian state and the organization of a peace conference under the aegis of the United Nations, conditions that clashed with US and Israeli positions.

title: Israel says it has recovered bodies of 3 hostages
summary: The military claimed the bodies of 3 hostages taken at the October 7 music festival, including the body of German-Israeli Shani Louk, were found overnight, without elaborating, and did not give immediate details on where they were located.

title: Paris by bike: Ten leafy pitstops from the Opéra to the Buttes-Chaumont park
summary: Black pines, paulownias, date palms and Japanese sophoras are just some of the remarkable trees featured in this bicycle tour of the capital's 9th to 19th arrondissements. These green pitstops are as educational as they are refreshing.

title: Police kill man trying to set fire to synagogue in Rouen, France
summary: According to Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin, the man was armed and 'clearly' wanted to set fire to the religious building.

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: Three major Paris roads closed to traffic from Friday
summary: The first road closures in Paris began on Friday, May 17, to allow for the construction of infrastructure for the Olympics.

title: Man who attacked Nancy Pelosi’s husband with a hammer sentenced to 30 years
summary: Right-wing conspiracy theorist David DePape broke into Nancy Pelosi's home in October 2022 in the hopes of kidnapping the then-House Speaker.

title: EU elections: Raphaël Glucksmann, the opponent Macron's camp never saw coming
summary: The presidential camp's strategy of ignoring the left-wing candidate is crumbling as the June 9 elections loom and Glucksmann is closing in on candidate Valérie Hayer.

title: France's La Poste celebrates baguette with bakery-scented stamp
summary: The French post office unveiled on Thursday, the day of the patron saint of bakers and pastry chefs, a scratch-and-sniff post stamp, which costs €1.96.

title: Putin rejects Macron's call for Ukraine ceasefire during Olympics
summary: The French president restated on Friday his idea of 'an Olympic truce so that Russia ceases its current operations' in Ukraine, to Putin's disapproval.

title: Ukrainian soldiers in Donbas are fed up waiting for Western munitions
summary: Neither the shells included in the 'Czech plan' announced this winter, nor those tied to US aid approved at the end of April, have reached the front line, undermining the morale of Ukrainian troops.

title: Slovak PM Fico's condition 'still very serious' after second surgery
summary: Robert Fico's condition was said to still be 'very serious' on Friday after it was reported he had a second operation following an attempted assassination.

title: South Pacific countries are watching France and how it handles New Caledonia situation
summary: The region's island nations are paying close attention to the violent crisis shaking the French overseas territory, and are calling for a return to dialogue in the archipelago.

title: The Netherlands' new coalition led by far right promises anti-migrant measures
summary: Geert Wilders, leader of the fat-right Party for Freedom, will not serve as prime minister but will lead the coalition.

title: Azerbaijan interference in New Caledonia is just part of the story
summary: The French government has accused Baku of aggravating the situation on the island, but while the country's role in past destabilization campaigns is undeniable, its involvement in the current tensions is uncertain.

title: Paris Olympics 2024: 500 recipes on the athletes' menu, but no burgers or fries
summary: The restaurant in the Athletes' Village, open 24/7 for the duration of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, will have to meet competitors' high standards, nutrition being key to sporting success.

title: Zelensky says Russian offensive on Kharkiv could be 'first wave' of attacks
summary: In an interview with AFP, Volodymyr Zelensky also rejected any idea of an Olympic truce, which had been floated by French President Macron.

title: Mediterranean wetland birds threatened by rising sea levels
summary: By 2100, one-third to one-half of the coastal wetlands in eight Mediterranean countries could be partially or completely submerged.

title: New details about a mysterious 1978 plane crash in Bulgaria
summary: A journalist's investigation into the crash of a Balkan Bulgarian Airlines plane in the late 1970s has given hope to the families of the victims, who until now have been kept in the dark, to shed light on the exact circumstances of the tragedy.

title: BJP election campaign in India revolves around cult of Modi
summary: The ruling party is hoping for a third consecutive victory in the upcoming election, relying on the prime minister's popularity and anti-Muslim sentiment to win over voters, but it remains evasive about its manifesto.

title: 'Cannes has always been composed of two sides – one aesthetic and the other political'
summary: Faced with the #MeToo movement and accusations against French film industry figures, the Festival is seeking to both champion the voices of women and continue to presume accused men are innocent, writes Le Monde culture columnist Michel Guerrin.

title: Senegal's new PM criticizes French military presence
summary: Ousmane Sonko, who became Prime Minister in April 2024, has repeatedly pushed for full self-determination for Senegal.

title: Eight ideas for European Night of Museums
summary: More than 3,000 museums will open their doors to the public free of charge on May 18. Here are our picks for how to make the most of the night in Paris and the surrounding region.

title: Meet the 'mid girl', the latest TikTok trend used to elicit compliments
summary: Anne Chirol looks at the 'mid girl,' a young woman who finds herself neither beautiful nor ugly, and who presents herself as a victim of popular beauty standards on social media.

title: Irish president criticizes UK's new 'Troubles' law
summary: The law has any inquests, civil cases and criminal prosecutions linked to the 'Troubles' in Northern Ireland.

title: EU accession has boosted growth among its new members
summary: A new report points out that per capita wealth of the 10 countries that joined the European Union in 2004 has risen from 14% to 50% that of Germany in 20 years.

title: Diversity managers in the US are facing new challenges
summary: Several recent lawsuits are driving American companies to review their programs for the inclusion of racial minorities.

title: Inside a Kyiv recruitment center: 'Someone has to hold a weapon'
summary: Ukrainians now have to identify themselves to the authorities to potentially be called to serve in the military. Le Monde follows two young Ukrainians who volunteered for the front before the change new rule came into effect.

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: What was promised and what will actually be ready?
summary: In 2016, Paris' bid for the 2024 Olympics boasted lofty ambitions. But as the city counts down the days until the opening ceremony on July 26, some of these promises have fallen through.

title: New Caledonia: One killed, two injured in new shooting
summary: Six people have now died since Monday in the French territory in the Pacific Ocean, which has seen a resurgence of violence as France's Parliament moves to reform the local electoral register.

title: Former Georgian president Saakashvili: 'The Russians want to take revenge'
summary: The imprisoned former president and opposition leader writes to Le Monde about Georgia's controversial 'foreign influence' law.

title: New Caledonia: Partial calm but gunfire in French territory under state of emergency
summary: A sixth person was killed in the archipelago on Saturday, following an exchange of fire in the North Province.

title: Heavy rains in Northern Europe cause floods
summary: There was flooding in parts of Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: Sudan paramilitaries say they will open 'safe passages' out of key Darfur city
summary: The Rapid Support Forces, which have been fighting the regular army for over a year, said they were willing to let citizens leave El-Fasher, the state capital of North Darfur, which they are seeking to control.

title: Delivery of aid to Gaza by sea is a 'smokescreen' given the scale of the needs
summary: The floating pier set up by the United States became operational on Friday, at a time when the Israeli army forced more than 600,000 people to leave the southern city of Rafah in chaos and particularly difficult sanitary conditions.

title: After the arson attack on Rouen's synagogue, shock and support for France's Jewish community
summary: The man who set fire to the building on Friday morning was killed by police. He was an undocumented Algerian whose application for a residency permit in France for health treatment had been rejected. Rallies were held in Rouen and Paris.

title: Paris 2024: 55,000 spectators turned out to cheer the Olympic torch in Toulouse
summary: The Olympic torch relay in Toulouse on Friday came to a climactic close in an enthusiastic Stade Ernest-Wallon.

title: Paris jeweller's near Champs-Elysées robbed by armed men
summary: The three men fired a warning shot but no one was injured, as they escaped with jewels from Harry Winston.

title: New Caledonia: Why are there so many guns in the French Pacific territory?
summary: French authorities estimate that there is one firearm for every four inhabitants on the archipelago's main island, Grande Terre.

title: Slovak PM's prognosis 'positive,' as shooting suspect in pre-trial detention
summary: Slovakia's Prime Minister Robert Fico, who was shot four times on Wednesday, is in 'stable' condition after undergoing more surgery on Friday, said the health minister.

title: For Palestinian citizens of Israel, commemorations of 1948 Nakba come with stigma
summary: The October 7 attack has increased mistrust of Israel's Palestinian community, which represents 20% of its population. Most demonstrations in solidarity with Gaza its members have tried to organize have been banned or dispersed.

title: Xi and Putin: A far from self-evident friendship
summary: The Chinese and Russian leaders frequently communicate directly and have a strong personal relationship, despite their dissimilar backgrounds.

title: Georgia's president vetoes 'foreign influence' law – but Parliament can override
summary: The ruling party has enough seats to overrule President Salome Zurabishvili's veto of the controversial law based on Russian legislation.

title: Iranian Nobel laureate Narges Mohammadi faces new trial, family says
summary: Narges Mohammadi, who is held in Tehran's Evin prison, is charged with making 'propaganda against the regime' in a trial set to begin Sunday, said her family.

title: Georgia's 'Family Purity Day': A show of support for the government
summary: Tens of thousands of people marched in Tbilisi on Friday for this celebration organized by the Orthodox Church. It was the government's way of responding to demonstrations against its 'foreign influence' bill.

title: New Caledonia's nickel: Key resource for archipelago and pro-independence movement
summary: The sector accounts for a quarter of direct and indirect employment, but it has been devastated by the cost of energy. For the pro-independence movement, control of this resource remains crucial to achieving full sovereignty.

title: New Caledonia removed from Olympic torch's route following unrest
summary: The French territory in the Pacific Ocean is under a state of emergency since violent clashes have broken out as French lawmakers adopted a constitutional reform to change voter lists there.
